title: 114_hr6250
content: The Act is titled the "Relief and Investment for Student Entrepreneurs Act" or the "RISE Act". It allows for the deferment of federal student loan payments for qualified entrepreneurs. Section 455(f) of the Higher Education Act of 1965 is amended to allow deferment of federal student loan payments for qualified entrepreneurs for up to 3 years. A qualified entrepreneur is defined as a borrower who received a degree from an institution. The Higher Education Act of 1965 is amended to allow deferment of federal student loan payments for qualified entrepreneurs for up to 3 years. Qualified entrepreneurs must meet specific criteria, including receiving a degree from an institution of higher education, registering a business entity, raising capital investment of at least $30,000, and having an outstanding loan balance of at least $5,000. Additionally, they must meet a minimum employee requirement to continue the deferment. The borrower must employ at least 2 full-time employees who are not relatives and pay them at least the state's minimum wage to continue deferment after 1 year. Loan cancellation for entrepreneurs is added to the Higher Education Act of 1965, allowing for loan forgiveness for entrepreneurs. The Secretary is authorized to cancel loan obligations for borrowers who have operated a qualified HUBZone small business for at least 3 years and are not in default on their loans. The maximum amount that can be canceled is $17,500 for Federal Direct Stafford Loans or Federal Direct Unsubsidized Stafford Loans. The Secretary can cancel loan obligations for borrowers who have run a qualified HUBZone small business for at least 3 years and are not in default on their loans. Loan forgiveness is granted on a first-come, first-served basis, subject to availability of funds. Loan consolidation amounts may qualify if used to repay specific types of loans. The publication and report requirements are outlined in Section 4. The Secretary of Education and the Administrator of the Small Business Administration must provide information on the student loan deferment program for qualified entrepreneurs on their respective websites. The Secretary of Education is also required to submit a report to Congress within 180 days, assessing the progress of the program and detailing efforts to increase participation.
